titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Edith Emerson Papers, 1839-1981, bulk 1894-1971, in the Archives of American Art AAA.emeredit
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Carrol Park

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-09-11T13:36-0400

did.abstract: The papers of painter, illustrator, and curator Edith Emerson measure 2.1 linear feet and date from 1839 to 1981, with the bulk of the material dating from 1894-1971. Found within the papers are biographical material; letters from friends and colleagues; writings and notes by Emerson and others; artwork, including three sketchbooks; subject files; photographs of Emerson, family, friends, and artwork; and scattered printed material.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The collection was processed by Jean Fitzgerald in 1991. A finding aid was written by Carrol Park in 2012.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Edith Emerson papers, 1839-1981, bulk 1849-1971. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials note
separatedmaterial.p: Edith Emerson lent four scrapbooks for microfilming in 1977. Loaned material is available on microfilm reels 1186-1187, but is not described in the container listing of this finding aid.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Papers were donated in 1990 by the Free Library of Philadelphia, who received them from Emerson.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Edith Emerson papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged as 7 series:

list.item: Series 3: Writings and Notes, 1887-1970 (Box 1; 0.3 linear feet)
Series 5: Subject Files, circa 1865-1955 (Box 1-2; 0.9 linear feet)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The papers of painter, illustrator, and curator Edith Emerson measure 2.1 linear feet and date from 1839 to 1981, with the bulk of the material dating from 1894-1971. Found within the papers are biographical material; letters from friends and colleagues; writings and notes by Emerson and others; artwork, including three sketchbooks; subject files; photographs of Emerson, family, friends, and artwork; and scattered printed material.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Edith Emerson (1888-1981) was a painter, illustrator, and curator in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania.

Born in Oxford, Ohio, Emerson studied at the Art Institute of Chicago with John Vanderpoel and Thomas Wood Stevens and at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts with Cecilia Beaux, Violet Oakley, and Daniel Garber. She assisted Violet Oakley primarily between 1917 and 1930 and shared her studio from 1918 until Oakley's death in 1961. Emerson served on the Board of Directors of the Woodmere Art Gallery beginning in 1940, subsequently becoming Curator. She was also a founding member of the Violet Oakley Memorial Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains two pages of typewritten biographical material about Edith Emerson, with a few handwritten annotations.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Letters are arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Within this series are personal and business letters. Included are letters between Edith Emerson and friends, as well as prospective clients for her artwork. Of note are letters from Margaret French Cresson, Elizabeth Shippen Green Elliott, Daniel Garber, Charles Hopkinson, Clare Leighton, and Henry McCarter. Also found are holiday cards to and from Edith Emerson.

Business letters typically concern job details, sales of artwork, or art related events. Of note are referral letters from McCall Magazine editors and letters between the Philadlphia Art Alliance concerning Mr. Bart Tourison's housing projects. There are handwritten notes by Edith Emerson on a few of the letters.

did.unittitle: Oversize Christmas Cards from Berta and Elmer Hader

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains writings and notes by Edith Emerson and others. Found here are an address book; a journal by Emerson's cousin, Mary Ingham, describing trips to Italy, Yellowstone, Holland, France, Germany, and Canada; an incomplete journal concerning travel to Great Britain and Germany; and notes on painting by Huger Elliott. Also found are a list of students at the Pennsylvania Museum School, a record of Emerson's exhibitions (1937-1970), and a manuscript "Cogslea Chronicles." Miscellaneous writings include a brief manuscript "Tales of Francis Joseph Fitz-Patrick."

did.unittitle: Address Book and Notebook Listing Books Read
List of Students at Pennsylvania Museum School
Material Inserted in Exhibition Record Notebook

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Within this series is artwork, mainly paintings and drawings, by Edith Emerson and others. Included are 33 drawings and three annotated sketchbooks by Emerson, including one of India; a painting by Jessie Arms Botke; and prints by John H. Beatty, Anna Lea Merritt, and others.

did.unittitle: Loose Drawings Inserted in Annotated Sketchbook

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Files are arranged alphabetically by subject.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Subject files were maintained by Edith Emerson. Files may contain letters, notes, photographs, and printed material. Of note are subject files on Cecilia Beaux, Elizabeth Shippen Green Elliott, Thornton Oakley, Ruth St. Denis, the Moorestown Trust Company, the Philadelphia Art Alliance, "Song of Roland" illustrations, the WPA Women's Activities Division, the Writers and Illustrators Exchange, and other topics.

did.unittitle: Beaux Arts Institute of Design, Philadelphia Atelier of Mural Painting
Philadelphia "Art Notes" (For American Magazine of Arts)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Found in this series are photographs of Edith Emerson and her friends, including a few with Violet Oakley. Also found are photographs of Emerson's family, photographs from a Mexico trip, interior views of her home and studio in Cogslea, works of art by Emerson, photographs of child models, and works of art by others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed materials include brochures; clippings documenting Emerson's career; exhibition announcements and catalogs for Emerson, Violet Oakley, and others; as well as other miscellaneous published items and printed reproductions of her work.
